page.title: 02Nether Stowey:Castle Mount
page.content: The dominant hill rising on the south west edge of Nether Stowey and called the Castle Mount is the remaining site of a 'motte and bailey' castle. It can be approached by Castle Hill on one side and from Mill Lane on the other. It was built for a Norman baron and later belonged to the family of Lord Audley, who was executed by Henry VII. It was finally destroyed in about 1497 and the stones were used to build a new home at Stowey Court for the Audley family. There are enough foundations of the castle left to see where the ground floor rooms were situated. At the foot of the hill is the mill stream, near to Audley Close. From the top of the Mount are fine panoramic views of the Bristol Channel, the Mendip Hills and Glastonbury Tor. The Mount, now owned by Mr Dinham, is used for grazing.
